III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 06/12/2024, youth was assaulted on two separate incidents by
fellow peers at the facility. He was taken to the ER where he
presented with a bruised left eye. It is unknown where facility staff
were during these incidents. On 06/13/2024, Youth was walking
outside of the facility, down the street to a gas station. He was not
accompanied by a facility staff, and it is unknown why. Youth
crossed path with a few unknown children who made requests of
him that he denied. The unknown group of children proceeded to
attack youth. Youth was taken to the ER where he is presenting
with pain in his head, hemorrhage in his left eye and swelling on
both sides of his head. His discharge status is unknown at this
time.
Investigation On 06/14/2024 an email correspondence was sent to the assigned
Foster Care Worker to advise of investigation.
All of the following interviews were conducted at the facility
on 06/20/2024 in collaboration with DHHS Specialist unless
otherwise noted.
Vice President of Residential Programs and Program Manager
were interviewed. Both administrators were advised of the
allegations. They confirmed that they were aware of the incident
and denied that their staff failed to provide supervision or engaged
in behavior that is not consistent with the agency policies and
procedures. Copies of the incident reports were provided and the
DHHS Specialist implement a safety plan with the agency. The
Program Manager advised that since Youth A got to Wolverine, he
has been going AWOL regularly and has been getting into
arguments with the other youth. She advised that Youth B
punched Youth A in the eye and staff quickly responded and de-
escalated it. She reported that Youth A had been spitting on staff
2

and residents which was making the residents angry with him.
Program Manager further advised that there is no video coverage
for review as the incident occurred at night and the agency
cameras do not pick up once it is dark outside.
Youth A was interviewed and admitted to leaving the facility on
his own without permission. Youth A reported that on the night of
the incident he was being disrespectful to staff (does not
remember which staff) and he went outside for a break. He was
followed by staff and Youth B. Youth A reported that Youth B
began to hit him in the head and in the back for no reason. He
reported the staff pulled Youth B off of him right away. Youth A
does not recall any other youth being present and stated it was at
night. He then stated that he thinks the staff was Staff 1. Youth A
then advised that the incident involving a fight with individuals in
the community was the following night, 6/13/2024. He reported he
went AWOL from Wolverine and four unknown boys from the
community jumped him. He recalled that it happened in an alley a
few blocks away from the agency. Youth A reported that after the
fight, he returned to Wolverine and the staff took him to the
hospital. Youth A admitted that he frequently AWOL’s from the
facility but failed to provide a reason why.
Staff 2 was interviewed. She reported that this incident between
Youth A and Youth B happened during second shift and she only
works first shift. She declined knowing specifics regarding the
incident but reported that staff consistently provide supervision of
youth and always intervene immediately if there is an altercation
between them. She also was able to confirm that Youth A
frequently AWOL’s from the program and “roams” the community.
Youth B was interviewed and reported that the incident began
due to Youth A spitting on him. Youth B further stated that he was
not interested in saying anything else to DHHS or Licensing. He
did indicate he does not have any concerns at Wolverine. Youth
B was asked several questions but refused to answer. Youth B did
add that he was not happy because Youth A spit on him and
confirmed that staff always provide supervision and intervene
when residents fight.
On 06/21/2024 a voicemail message was left for complainant
requesting a return call with any additional concerns.
On 06/27/2024 Youth C was interviewed at Wolverine and DHHS
Specialist 2 was also present. Youth C reported that he did not
recall the incident between Youth A and Youth B but was aware
3

that Youth A frequently AWOL’s from the agency and spends time
in the neighborhood. Youth C confirmed that Youth A went AWOL
within the last 24 to 48 hours. Youth C confirmed that staff
provides supervision and intervenes when there are issues
between youth.
On 06/27/2024 unsuccessful attempts were made to contact Staff
1, Staff 3, and Supervisor 1 via telephone.
On 06/28/2024 a telephone conversation was held with DHHS
Specialist 1. She confirmed the scheduled Case Conference
meeting and advised of successful telephone contact with
Supervisor 1. She stated that he confirmed that he was
contacted via radio by Staff 1 for assistance outside with Youth A
and Youth B. He reported that he did not see the initial incident,
but when he arrived outside, he observed Staff 1 and Staff 3 trying
to separate the boys. He added that both staff were appropriate in
their actions, and he noted no concerns.
On 06/28/2024 a DHHS Closing Case Conference was held.
DHHS Specialist noted there were no findings of abuse or neglect.
Licensing advised that preliminary findings did not note any areas
of non-compliance, however advised that the investigation was
still pending. It was noted during the case conference that Youth
A is now placed at a secure facility.
On 07/03/2024 an unsuccessful attempt was made to reach Staff
3 via telephone.
On 07/03/2024 an interview of Staff 1 was completed via
telephone along with DHHS Specialist. Staff 1 confirmed that she
is a youth specialist at Wolverine. She stated on the day of the
incident with Youth A and Youth B, she recalled it being dark and
they were outside in front of the building. She stated they were
outside because Youth A had been getting into it with other
residents, so they went outside for him to “cool down”. She stated
that Youth A was initially calm but began yelling once Youth B
came outside. Youth A balled up his fist at her and she believed
that Youth B thought Youth A was about to hit her sohe stepped
in. The youth began to fight and she said she stood up and tried
to get between them. Staff 1 reported that Youth A swung on
Youth B first and then spit on him. Youth B then reached around
her and swung on Youth A. Staff 1 recalled that Staff 3 came
outside after Youth B came outside. She reported they both were
trying to stop the boys from fighting each other. She reported she
radioed for staff to come outside and assist in breaking up the
4

fight and Supervisor 1 responded. Staff 1 reported that Youth A
likes to instigate things with other residents and get in their
business. She also stated he goes AWOL regularly. Staff 1
reported that she and other staff work hard to provide supervision
of the youth in the program and always intervene if there are
altercations between residents.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally
redirect the truanting client and will offer the client support and
alternatives to truancy. If a non supervising staff is available, they
will walk with the client and continue to provide verbal support and
redirection encouraging the client not to truant.
Staff supervising the group will immediately call a group attention
to support and maintain the security of the group. Staff will
maintain control of the group and conduct an immediate head
count. Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15
minutes from loss of line of sight (when youth is determined
AWOL). The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management who will provide oversight
for incident management. The youth specialist supervisor will
ensure law enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5
minutes from when youth is determined AWOL.) Staff will report
the following information immediately to the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty Name(s) of the truant client(s), Approximate
time and location of the truancy, The direction of travel the
client(s) was/were headed, Whether the client(s) appear(s) to
present a danger to self or others in the community,
circumstances prior to the truancy, risk assessment and other
pertinent safety related information. Staff will notify law
enforcement and program director. Client specifics will be
provided to Law enforcement and an IR will be completed.
Incident Report for 6/12/2024: Writer of report was Staff 1 and it
also indicated that Staff 3 was present. It documented that Youth
A was yelling at Staff 1 and acting like he was going to hit her.
Youth B walked outside and observed the behavior of Youth A
and got in the middle of Youth A and Staff 1 and pushed Youth A.
Youth B was heard stating that he was tired of Youth A
disrespecting the staff. Staff 1 and Staff 3 reported trying to pull
the two youth apart as they were fighting and radioed for
supervisor assistance. The incident occurred around 9:15 p.m.
Staff completed a body chart and documented that the nose of
Youth A was bleeding and his eye was bruised. Youth A was
transported to St. John Hospital after the incident.
5

Incident Report for 6/13/2024: Documented that Youth A
returned to facility by police around 11:30 PM from AWOL status.
Youth A reported he was jumped by some neighborhood kids
while walking in the community and he was transported to hospital
for evaluation. It was noted that Youth A had injury to the same
eye that was injured in the 6/12/24 incident.
Wolverine Supervision Policy: Indicates the primary job of all
staff is to maintain adequate coverage and Line of Sight of all
clients. Specifically, this means that the clients are never left
unattended for any amount of time and that you can view all
behavior of the client you supervise. This ensures that client in
your care will not be abused; sexually, emotionally and/or
physically.
St. John Medical Report: Medical report documents that Youth
A was treated on 6/14/24 after reporting an assault at a gas
station on 6/13/2024. The diagnosis was unspecified injury of
head, assault by unspecified means. Youth A was given ice and
DHHS was contacted. Youth placed on hold in stable condition.
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance with the licensing
rules. Both staff and youth were interviewed, and no evidence
was found to support the allegations of a lack of supervision or
lack of sufficiency of staff during this incident. Staff appropriately
responded and intervened when the youth were fighting and was
unable to provide supervision to the youth while he was in the
community due to his AWOL status.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
